name: Jean-Philippe Lenclos
biography:
Jean-Philippe Lenclos is a designer, colorist, and founder of Atelier 3D Couleur, a studio based in Paris that specializes in the conception and application of color in the environment, architecture, and industrial products. 
Lenclos’ interest in symbolism and color theory began at an early age and has developed in his designs and writing ever since. He and his wife Dominique Lenclos are co-authors of several books on color, including the Geography of Color and Colors of the World, which have won numerous awards. Lenclos taught color theory at École Nationale Supérieure des Arts Décoratifs for several years. 
In 1960 Lenclos received a scholarship to study at the Kyoto City University Fine Arts School where he focused on calligraphy, which later became the basis of his graphic and pictorial designs. In 1972 he exhibited a synthetic study on the Colors of Tokyo at the Ichiban Gallery in Tokyo. By 1977 Lenclos had amassed a great degree of recognition in France and his work was shown in a monographic exhibition at the Centre Georges-Pompidou.
